hints_html:
Try to modify the integrand in order to perform a trigonometric substitution.

Complete the square in the denominator and make an appropriate trigonometric substitution.
hints_latex:
Try to modify the integrand in order to perform a trigonometric
substitution.

Complete the square in the denominator and make an appropriate
trigonometric substitution.
hints_raw:
Try to modify the integrand in order to perform a trigonometric substitution.
Complete the square in the denominator and make an appropriate trigonometric substitution.
question: 3 (c)
sols_html:
We want to integrate:

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{dx}{(5 - 4x - x^2)^{3/2}}.\end{aligned}\]

The first step is to complete the square in the denominator:

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{dx}{(9 - 4 - 4x - x^2)^{3/2}} &= \int \frac{dx}{(9 - (x + 2)^2)^{3/2}} \\ &= \int \frac{1}{27} \; \frac{dx}{(1 - \frac{(x + 2)^2}{9})^{3/2}} \\ &= \frac{1}{27} \int \frac{dx}{(1 - (\frac{x + 2}{3})^2)^{3/2}} \end{aligned}\]

Now we substitute:

\[\begin{aligned} y = \frac{x + 2}{3}\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} dy = \frac{dx}{3}\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 3 dy = dx,\end{aligned}\]

So the integral simplifies to

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{3}{27} \int \frac{dy}{(1 - y^2)^{3/2}} = \frac{1}{9} \int \frac{dy}{(1- y^2)^{3/2}}\end{aligned}\]

We now perform a trigonometric substitution (this step is only valid for y smaller than 1, which we know is true because 1-y^2 must be positive):

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y = \sin(t)\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle dy = \cos(t) dt\end{aligned}\]

So the above integral becomes:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{9} \int \frac{\cos(t) dt}{(1 - \sin^2(t))^{3/2}} &= \frac{1}{9} \int \frac{\cos(t) dt}{(\cos^2(t))^{3/2})} \\ &= \frac{1}{9} \int \frac{dt}{\cos^2(t)}\\ &= \frac{1}{9} \int \sec^2(t) dt\\ &= \frac{1}{9} \tan(t) + C\\ &= \frac{1}{9} \tan( \arcsin(y)) + C\\ &= \frac{1}{9} \tan(\arcsin(\frac{ x + 2}{3})) + C \end{aligned}\]

But for any u, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \tan( \arcsin(u)) = \frac{u}{\sqrt{1 - u^2}},\end{aligned}\]

So the above quantity is equal to

\[\begin{aligned} = \frac{1}{9} \; \frac{ \frac{x + 2}{3}}{\sqrt{1 - (\frac{x + 2}{3})^2}}\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} = \frac {1}{9} \; \frac{x + 2}{\sqrt{5 -4x - x^2}}.\end{aligned}\]

So we have

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{dx}{(5 - 4x -x^2)^{3/2}} = \frac{1}{9} \; \frac{x + 2}{\sqrt{5 - 4x - x^2}}.\end{aligned}\]

This is not required in a test, but we can check our answer by differentiating:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dx} \; \frac{1}{9} \; \frac{x+2}{\sqrt{5 - 4x - x^2}}\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} &= \frac{1}{9} \; \frac{\sqrt{5 - 4x - x^2} - \frac{1}{2} (x + 2)(5 - 4x - x^2)^{-1/2} (-2x - 4)}{(5 - 4x - x^2)} \\ &= \frac{1}{9} \; \frac{5 - 4x - x^2 + x^2 + 2x + 2x + 4}{(5 - 4x - x^2)^{3/2}}\\ &= \frac{1}{9} \; \frac{9}{(5 - 4x - x^2)^{3/2}}\\ &= \frac{1}{(5 - 4x - x^2)^{3/2}} \end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
We want to integrate:

:<math>\int \frac{dx}{(5 - 4x - x^2)^{3/2}}.</math>

The first step is to complete the square in the denominator:

:<math>\begin{align}\int \frac{dx}{(9 - 4 - 4x - x^2)^{3/2}} &= \int \frac{dx}{(9 - (x + 2)^2)^{3/2}} \\
&= \int \frac{1}{27} \; \frac{dx}{(1 - \frac{(x + 2)^2}{9})^{3/2}} \\
&= \frac{1}{27} \int \frac{dx}{(1 - (\frac{x + 2}{3})^2)^{3/2}} \end{align}</math>

Now we substitute:

:<math> y = \frac{x + 2}{3} </math>

:<math> dy = \frac{dx}{3} </math>

:<math> \displaystyle 3 dy = dx, </math>

So the integral simplifies to

:<math> \frac{3}{27} \int \frac{dy}{(1 - y^2)^{3/2}} = \frac{1}{9} \int \frac{dy}{(1- y^2)^{3/2}} </math>

We now perform a trigonometric substitution (this step is only valid for |y| smaller than 1, which we know is true because 1-y^2 must be positive):

:<math> \displaystyle y = \sin(t) </math>

:<math> \displaystyle dy = \cos(t) dt</math>

So the above integral becomes:

:<math> \begin{align}\frac{1}{9} \int \frac{\cos(t) dt}{(1 - \sin^2(t))^{3/2}} &= \frac{1}{9} \int \frac{\cos(t) dt}{(\cos^2(t))^{3/2})} \\
&= \frac{1}{9} \int \frac{dt}{\cos^2(t)}\\
&= \frac{1}{9} \int \sec^2(t) dt\\
&= \frac{1}{9} \tan(t) + C\\
&= \frac{1}{9} \tan( \arcsin(y)) + C\\
&= \frac{1}{9} \tan(\arcsin(\frac{ x + 2}{3})) + C \end{align}</math>

But for any ''u'', we have

:<math> \tan( \arcsin(u)) = \frac{u}{\sqrt{1 - u^2}}, </math>

So the above quantity is equal to

:<math> = \frac{1}{9} \; \frac{ \frac{x + 2}{3}}{\sqrt{1 - (\frac{x + 2}{3})^2}} </math>

:<math> = \frac {1}{9} \; \frac{x + 2}{\sqrt{5 -4x - x^2}}.</math>

So we have

:<math> \int \frac{dx}{(5 - 4x -x^2)^{3/2}} = \frac{1}{9} \;  \frac{x + 2}{\sqrt{5 - 4x - x^2}}. </math>


''This is not required in a test, but we can check our answer by differentiating:''

:<math> \frac{d}{dx} \; \frac{1}{9} \; \frac{x+2}{\sqrt{5 - 4x - x^2}} </math>

::<math> \begin{align}&= \frac{1}{9} \; \frac{\sqrt{5 - 4x - x^2} - \frac{1}{2} (x + 2)(5 - 4x - x^2)^{-1/2}  (-2x - 4)}{(5 - 4x - x^2)} \\
&= \frac{1}{9} \; \frac{5 - 4x - x^2 + x^2 + 2x + 2x + 4}{(5 - 4x - x^2)^{3/2}}\\
&= \frac{1}{9} \; \frac{9}{(5 - 4x - x^2)^{3/2}}\\
&= \frac{1}{(5 - 4x - x^2)^{3/2}} \end{align}</math>

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \int \frac{dx}{(5 - 4x - x^{2})^{3/2}}\end{aligned}\]
